docs.lead_paragraph: Several former National Basketball Association players, including ALEX ENGLISH, DAVE COWENS, OSCAR ROBERTSON and JERRY WEST, gathered yesterday without a basketball in sight. They were in Manhattan to announce the first marketing venture of an organization known as XPRO, the association of retired professional basketball players. XPRO was formed to create a support system for the hundreds of former players who pioneered and popularized the game before the existence of adequate pension plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Twelve pounds heavier from nights of burgers and room service, Bill Bradley returned recently from a trip around the country to promote the book he wrote that made him realize he no longer wished to be a United States Senator. His head was overfull with the issues he wants to tackle, now that he will soon be free of elective office as he stews, maybe for the last time, over whether he could, or even should, try to become President.

headline.main: Bradley, Retiring Senator, Pondering His Next Shot;He Hasn't Decided What His Role Will Be

docs.lead_paragraph: Buffeted by the changes sweeping health care, the 60-year-old Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association is struggling to preserve its franchise as the nation's biggest and best-known group of health insurers. Mergers and buyouts are transforming plans built on traditions of local public service into multistate businesses. More than 50 of the historically nonprofit Blues have started for-profit units. And in what some plan executives see as a threat to the entire system, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio recently agreed to sell its main business to the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's biggest investor-owned hospital chain.

headline.main: Soul-Searching at Blue Cross in Face of Change

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about health insurance legislation misstated the Clinton Administration's views on one provision. While the Administration has long opposed the inclusion of medical savings accounts in the bill, its veto threat first occurred on Sunday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bob Dole today ended more than a decade as a Senate Republican leader, his tenure notable for deep commitment to the sometimes conflicting goals of deficit reduction, his party and the Senate itself. No Republican before him matched his 11 years 5 months as leader in the majority, the minority and the majority again. His years in S-230, a grand suite of Capitol offices looking down the Mall toward the Washington Monument, were marked by a day-in, day-out dedication to the job, with but two major distractions: his losing bid for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination and the campaign this year when success prompted his retirement.

docs.lead_paragraph: Employers' Rights Upheld In Early-Retirement Plans In a closely watched labor case involving Lockheed Martin, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that employers can require workers to give up various legal claims against a company as the price of receiving an early-retirement buyout with enhanced pension benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the eve of Bob Dole's departure from the Senate, Congressional Republicans agreed tonight on a health insurance bill -- but with a provision for medical savings accounts that could invite a veto from President Clinton. The immediate White House reaction was not dismissive, though. John Hilley, assistant to the President for legislative affairs, met with Republican Congressional aides tonight and praised them for "a good-faith proposal."

headline.main: Latest Health Insurance Bill Encounters Less Hostility

docs.snippet: On the eve of Bob Dole's departure from the Senate, Congressional Republicans agreed tonight on a health insurance bill -- but with a provision for medical savings accounts that could invite a veto from President Clinton.         The immediate White...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration today threatened to veto a health insurance bill if Republicans insist on including a large-scale program of medical savings accounts, and Representative Dick Armey, the House Republican floor leader, dared the President to do it. Others in each party said they still hoped a compromise could be worked out, but neither Administration nor Congressional aides involved with the issue said any progress had been made over the weekend. Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader and likely Republican Presidential nominee, has frequently said he would like to see a bill passed before he leaves the Senate on Tuesday.

headline.main: White House Says Provision Endangers Health Bill
